results.title: Thirty million letters
results.creator_credit: James Ritchie, Edgar H. Anstey, General Post Office and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: Every night in Britain, thirty million letters go through the post. This film shows the processes behind the safe delivery of this mail with emphasis on the travelling post office, and sorting, transport and delivery from Euston Station. The film also sees the service from the postman’s point of view, whether at work in the Outer Hebrides or on a daily round in London.

results.title: Thirty-six weeks behaviour day
results.creator_credit: Arnold Gesell and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: The infant boy whose behaviour day at 12 weeks was charted is now 36 weeks old. His reactions are compared with those which he experienced 24 weeks earlier. His responses to the ministrations of his father and mother are commented upon. The very first successful crawling efforts are observed.

results.title: Thirteen days = Thirteen days that shocked the world
results.creator_credit: Roger Donaldson, Mary Montiforte, Paul Deacon, Kevin Costner, Armyan Bernstein, Peter O Almond and Beacon Communications, Tig Productions
results.brief_description: Based on the book “The Kennedy Tapes - inside the White House During the Cuban Missile Crisis” by Ernest R. May and Philip D. Zelikow, “Thirteen Days” is a riveting drama about one of the most significant moments in the Cold War. Set almost entirely in the White House the film examines President John Kennedy’s (Bruce Greenwood) role in the Crisis, his relationship with his brother Robert (Steven Culp) - the then Attorney General of the USA - and the crucial role played by the President’s political advisor, Kenny O’Donnell (Kevin Costner). Simply but elegantly shot by Andrzej Bartkowiak and featuring a well-researched and structured screenplay by David Self, the film approaches a near-documentary realism. Roger Donaldson’s taut direction builds a consistent tension without sacrificing the complexities of the historical drama. Undoubtedly the closest the world has come to a nuclear war, the film establishes the diplomatic and military stand-off between the USA and the USSR as the key foreign affairs event for both President Kennedy and for Soviet leader Kruschev. This film is an excellent political thriller, its impact made more chillingly frightening by our knowledge of the catastrophic consequences of one wrong, or ill-communicated, political decision.

results.title: Thirteen conversations about one thing = 13 conversations ab
results.creator_credit: Jill Sprecher, Gina Resnick, Beni Atoori, Echo Lake Productions and Stonelock Pictures
results.brief_description: What is happiness? Through the journey of the everyday, five individuals’ lives link in a way that alters their fate or outlook. Karma, hope and fate are explored in this tale set in amongst busy city dwellers all with the need to answer life’s eternal questions of ‘what is life?’, ‘what’s in it for me?’ and even ‘how do I relate to others?’ Co-written and directed by Jill Sprecher. Stellar ensemble cast includes John Turturro, Matthew McConaughey, Clea DuVall, Amy Irving, Tia Texada, Barbara Sukowa, Alan Arkin.

results.title: Thirsty season
results.creator_credit: Jan Sharp, Richard Davis, Traffic Accident Research Unit and Laughing Kookaburra Productions
results.brief_description: Deals with the making of a beer commercial. Raises issues about the influence of the mass media on community attitudes, and the way in which this beer advertisement is structured to create preferences for a particular brand.

results.title: Thirst
results.creator_credit: Graham Chase, Robin Hughes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: One of three films as part of the National Drug Education Program which take an in-depth view of drug addiction in the day-to-day lives of ordinary people. Bob, a travelling salesman in children’s wear is an alcoholic. Although his is a loving family, his drinking and gambling cause his wife great stress and anguish. His drinking leaves him with little or nothing for housekeeping and expenses as he often “drinks” away his wages. Bob wants to lead a normal life and “tomorrow he’ll be sober”, but for him, tomorrow never comes. Photography by Dean Semler. (See also “All in the same boat” T/C 012758 and “Hassles” T/C 012851).

results.title: Third world cop [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Christopher Browne, Carolyn Pfeiffer, Hawk's Nest Productions, Island Jamaica Films and Palm Pictures
results.brief_description: Filmed on location in the raw and gritty back streets of modern day Kingston, Jamaica, this action-packed cop thriller tells the story of two friends whose lives have taken them in very different directions. Crime fighter Capone (Paul Campbell) is transferred back to his hometown where he encounters his long time friend Ratty (Mark Danvers) who not only is the right-hand man of the notorious local don, Wonie (Carl Bradshaw), but is also involved in gun-smuggling. Each tries to convince the other to change sides grimly putting their loyalty to one another to the test. But it is their friendship, however, which unfortunately suffers, finally ending in tragic and violent circumstances. “Third world cop” has many classic, sometimes corny, one-liners and is accompanied by a cool laid back soundtrack (produced by Sly & Robbie) of some great reggae and dancehall music performed by Sly & Robbie, Beenie Man, Luciano, Marley Brothers Featuring Ghetto Youths Crew, Lady G, Red Dragon among others. The film, a huge hit in Jamaica and becoming that country’s highest grossing film of all time also features many of the same production team that created “Dancehall queen” (1997), including actor Audrey Reid who plays Capone’s childhood sweetheart, Rita. Cast also includes Winston Bell, Lenford Salmon, Desmond Ballentine aka Ninjaman with cinematography by Richard Lannaman. In English but also contains English subtitles intermittently throughout.

results.title: Third dimension
results.creator_credit: Laurence Hyde and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In this survey of modern Canadian sculpture, man’s desire to give a third-dimensional form to his image is seen both in the child’s mudpies and in the greatest commemorative monuments. Techniques of the sculptor’s art - carving in wood and stone, clay modelling, making a plaster mold for metal casting - are demonstrated by leading Canadian sculptors, in a survey which extends from totem poles and early French woodcarving to the great war memorial on Vimy Ridge. Included are Jacobine Jones, Frances Loring, Donald Stewart, Louis Parent and Dora Weschler, as well as Emmanuel Hahn with his designs for coins.
